elements.content: Separation is one of the most energy-intensive processes in the chemical industry, and membrane-based separation technology helps to reduce the energy consumption dramatically. Supported metal–organic framework (MOF) layers hold great promise as a molecular sieve membrane, yet only a few MOF membranes showed the expected separation performance. The main reasons include e.g. nonselective grain boundary transport or the flexible MOF framework, especially the inevitable linker rotation. Here, we propose a crystal engineering strategy that balances the grain boundary structure and framework flexibility in Co–Zn bimetallic zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) membranes and exploit their contributions to the improvement of membrane quality and separation performance. It reveals that a good balance between the two trade-off factors enabled a “sweet spot” that offers the best C3H6/C3H8 separation factor up to 200.
elements.clean_text: Separation is one of the most energy-intensive processes in the chemical industry, and membrane-based separation technology helps to reduce the energy consumption dramatically. Supported metal-organic framework (MOF) layers hold great promise as a molecular sieve membrane, yet only a few MOF membranes showed the expected separation performance. The main reasons include e.g. nonselective grain boundary transport or the flexible MOF framework, especially the inevitable linker rotation. Here, we propose a crystal engineering strategy that balances the grain boundary structure and framework flexibility in Co-Zn bimetallic zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) membranes and exploit their contributions to the improvement of membrane quality and separation performance. It reveals that a good balance between the two trade-off factors enabled a "sweet spot" that offers the best C3H6/C3H8 separation factor up to 200.

elements.content: Propylene (C3H6) is one of the most important raw materials to manufacture plastics, and the purity determines its end use. Purification of propylene in industry is accomplished by removing propylene from the propylene/propane (C3H6/C3H8) mixture via energy-intensive cryogenic distillation. Accordingly, developing the energy-saving and eco-friendly membrane-based separation technology is greatly impactful. Among all kinds of membranes, molecular sieving membranes can selectively separate two different species according to their size and shape, but one of the challenges is to select a proper material with suitable sieving apertures. Zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) membranes, with regular pore size and adjustable structure, have been extensively developed as supported polycrystalline membranes or mixed matrix membranes. Especially ZIF-8 (or MAF-4) and ZIF-67, assembled from Zn2+ or Co2+ with the 2-methylimidazole (2-mIm) organic linker and sharing the same zeolitic sodalite topology, have a similar six-membered ring window size of ∼3.4 Å derived from X-ray diffraction (XRD) data. However, it is reported that molecules up to ∼4.2 Å can be adsorbed due to MOF framework flexibility. Through analyzing pure component permeability, Koros concluded that the effective aperture size of ZIF-8 is 4.0 to 4.2 Å. On one hand, the flexibility makes its effective aperture size fall between the kinetic diameters of C3H6 (4.0 Å) and C3H8 (4.2 Å), thus making it promising for C3H6/C3H8 separation. On the other hand, the intrinsic flexible structure might limit the further enhancement of C3H6/C3H8 separation selectivity because larger molecules can be permitted to pass through.
elements.clean_text: Propylene (C3H6) is one of the most important raw materials to manufacture plastics, and the purity determines its end use. Purification of propylene in industry is accomplished by removing propylene from the propylene/propane (C3H6/C3H8) mixture via energy-intensive cryogenic distillation. Accordingly, developing the energy-saving and eco-friendly membrane-based separation technology is greatly impactful. Among all kinds of membranes, molecular sieving membranes can selectively separate two different species according to their size and shape, but one of the challenges is to select a proper material with suitable sieving apertures. Zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) membranes, with regular pore size and adjustable structure, have been extensively developed as supported polycrystalline membranes or mixed matrix membranes. Especially ZIF-8 (or MAF-4) and ZIF-67, assembled from Zn2+ or Co2+ with the 2-methylimidazole (2-mIm) organic linker and sharing the same zeolitic sodalite topology, have a similar six-membered ring window size of ~3.4 Å derived from X-ray diffraction (XRD) data. However, it is reported that molecules up to ~4.2 Å can be adsorbed due to MOF framework flexibility. Through analyzing pure component permeability, Koros concluded that the effective aperture size of ZIF-8 is 4.0 to 4.2 Å. On one hand, the flexibility makes its effective aperture size fall between the kinetic diameters of C3H6 (4.0 Å) and C3H8 (4.2 Å), thus making it promising for C3H6/C3H8 separation. On the other hand, the intrinsic flexible structure might limit the further enhancement of C3H6/C3H8 separation selectivity because larger molecules can be permitted to pass through.

elements.content: In general, there are four ways to suppress the MOF flexibility: (a) electrochemical synthesis of stiffened MOF structure, (b) introduction of a larger ligand, (c) replacement of metal ions, and (d) coating a polymer layer on the MOF surface. We have proven that for soft porous materials, such as ZIF-8, suppressing the flexibility can enhance the molecular sieving capability. Compared with ZIF-8, the ZIF-67 framework is more rigid since the Co–N bond is shorter and stiffer than the Zn–N bond. Theoretical calculations also supported ZIF-67 being a better candidate than ZIF-8 for propylene purification. Nevertheless, few ZIF-67 membranes exhibited better experimental C3H6/C3H8 separation performance than ZIF-8 membranes except for the ZIF-8/ZIF-67/ZIF-8 triple layer membrane.
elements.clean_text: In general, there are four ways to suppress the MOF flexibility: (a) electrochemical synthesis of stiffened MOF structure, (b) introduction of a larger ligand, (c) replacement of metal ions, and (d) coating a polymer layer on the MOF surface. We have proven that for soft porous materials, such as ZIF-8, suppressing the flexibility can enhance the molecular sieving capability. Compared with ZIF-8, the ZIF-67 framework is more rigid since the Co-N bond is shorter and stiffer than the Zn-N bond. Theoretical calculations also supported ZIF-67 being a better candidate than ZIF-8 for propylene purification. Nevertheless, few ZIF-67 membranes exhibited better experimental C3H6/C3H8 separation performance than ZIF-8 membranes except for the ZIF-8/ZIF-67/ZIF-8 triple layer membrane.

elements.content: We speculated that the unsatisfactory separation performance of ZIF-67 membranes arises from the poor grain boundary structure since the crystallization kinetics of ZIF-67 is faster than that of ZIF-8. Accordingly, in bilayer ZIF membranes, ZIF-67 serves as a nonselective support for the ZIF-8 top layer. However, the ultrafast growth of ZIF-67 weakens the intergrowth of the crystals thus leading to defects. Therefore, to prepare membranes with a higher separation factor, the grain boundary must grow together.
elements.clean_text: We speculated that the unsatisfactory separation performance of ZIF-67 membranes arises from the poor grain boundary structure since the crystallization kinetics of ZIF-67 is faster than that of ZIF-8. Accordingly, in bilayer ZIF membranes, ZIF-67 serves as a nonselective support for the ZIF-8 top layer. However, the ultrafast growth of ZIF-67 weakens the intergrowth of the crystals thus leading to defects. Therefore, to prepare membranes with a higher separation factor, the grain boundary must grow together.

elements.content: Orientation control over the polycrystalline MOF is effective to improve the grain boundary structure (Table S1). We recently succeeded in preparing oriented MOF membranes via nonhomologous metal sources. In this work, we prepared a series of Zn2+/Co2+ ZIF membranes in one step within 20 min using the fast current driven synthesis (FCDS) method, by introducing Zn2+ into the precursor solution of ZIF-67 membranes (). Coupling ultrafast current driven growth with the nonhomologous crystallization results in the preferred orientation and better grain boundary structure of the bimetallic membranes, which is beneficial to improve the separation performance. However, the introduction of the Zn–N bond would weaken the MOF lattice rigidity, which is unfavorable to achieve exact molecular sieving. Consequently, to obtain the optimal separation performance of the bimetallic membranes, the perfect balance between the grain boundary structure and the framework flexibility is necessary.
elements.clean_text: Orientation control over the polycrystalline MOF is effective to improve the grain boundary structure (Table S1). We recently succeeded in preparing oriented MOF membranes via nonhomologous metal sources. In this work, we prepared a series of Zn2+/Co2+ ZIF membranes in one step within 20 min using the fast current driven synthesis (FCDS) method, by introducing Zn2+ into the precursor solution of ZIF-67 membranes (). Coupling ultrafast current driven growth with the nonhomologous crystallization results in the preferred orientation and better grain boundary structure of the bimetallic membranes, which is beneficial to improve the separation performance. However, the introduction of the Zn-N bond would weaken the MOF lattice rigidity, which is unfavorable to achieve exact molecular sieving. Consequently, to obtain the optimal separation performance of the bimetallic membranes, the perfect balance between the grain boundary structure and the framework flexibility is necessary.

elements.content: Schematic illustration of the design of bimetallic Zn(100–x)Co x -ZIF membranes. A balance between the lattice rigidity and grain boundary structure is beneficial to obtain the optimal separation selectivity. However, considering one factor too much (framework rigidity or grain boundary) while ignoring the other is unfavorable for high sieving ability.
elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic illustration of the design of bimetallic Zn(100-x)Co x -ZIF membranes. A balance between the lattice rigidity and grain boundary structure is beneficial to obtain the optimal separation selectivity. However, considering one factor too much (framework rigidity or grain boundary) while ignoring the other is unfavorable for high sieving ability.

elements.content: To exploit this concept, we prepared a series of Zn(100–x)Co x -ZIF membranes (x is the molar percentage of Co in the membranes) by FCDS. All membranes exhibit continuous polycrystalline layers without cracks, connecting well with the support with thicknesses thinner than 700 nm ( and Figure S1). The colorful thin-film optical interference phenomenon demonstrates a smooth membrane surface and agrees well with our previous membranes (Figure S3).
elements.clean_text: To exploit this concept, we prepared a series of Zn(100-x)Co x -ZIF membranes (x is the molar percentage of Co in the membranes) by FCDS. All membranes exhibit continuous polycrystalline layers without cracks, connecting well with the support with thicknesses thinner than 700 nm ( and Figure S1). The colorful thin-film optical interference phenomenon demonstrates a smooth membrane surface and agrees well with our previous membranes (Figure S3).

elements.content: (a–h) Cross-sectional SEM images of the Zn(100–x)Co x -ZIF membranes. The membrane layers connect well with the support with thicknesses thinner than 700 nm. (i–j) XRD patterns of the bimetallic membranes compared with the pure ZIF-67 (100% Co). The intensity of the (002) reflection of the bimetallic membranes varied a lot, indicating the bimetallic membranes show different degrees of orientation.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a-h) Cross-sectional SEM images of the Zn(100-x)Co x -ZIF membranes. The membrane layers connect well with the support with thicknesses thinner than 700 nm. (i-j) XRD patterns of the bimetallic membranes compared with the pure ZIF-67 (100% Co). The intensity of the (002) reflection of the bimetallic membranes varied a lot, indicating the bimetallic membranes show different degrees of orientation.

elements.content: Both Zn2+ and Co2+ distribute homogeneously (Figure S2), and their real percentages (Zn% and Co%) were confirmed by Inductively Coupled Plasma-Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS). Zn% and Co% in the membranes are not always consistent with those in the solution but show positive correlation (Table S2, Figure S4). Here, the degree of framework flexibility for the bimetallic membranes is described by Co%, since Co% is the only factor to influence the framework rigidity in this work and more Co existing in the membranes means more Co–N bonding in the frameworks, thus the stiffer nature of the lattice.
elements.clean_text: Both Zn2+ and Co2+ distribute homogeneously (Figure S2), and their real percentages (Zn% and Co%) were confirmed by Inductively Coupled Plasma-Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS). Zn% and Co% in the membranes are not always consistent with those in the solution but show positive correlation (Table S2, Figure S4). Here, the degree of framework flexibility for the bimetallic membranes is described by Co%, since Co% is the only factor to influence the framework rigidity in this work and more Co existing in the membranes means more Co-N bonding in the frameworks, thus the stiffer nature of the lattice.

elements.content: The bimetallic membranes were then characterized by XRD and Attenuated Total Reflection Infrared Spectroscopy (ATR-IR), and all the XRD and ATR-IR patterns of the membranes match well with those of simulated ZIF-67 (i–j, Figure S5). Especially from XRD results, we find the relative intensity of the (002) reflection of the bimetallic membranes significantly changes with Co%. It means the bimetallic membranes show different degrees of orientation (Figure S6, Table S3), which can be expressed by the Orientation Index (OI). Since a large OI value (>1) indicates an increasing orientation and the oriented MOF layer is beneficial to obtain a better grain boundary structure, here we use OI values to define the quality of the membrane grain boundary structures. It is reported that ZIF-8 membranes often have good grain boundary structures, so a small substitution percentage of Zn for Co (such as 10%) will not cause significant damage to the frameworks; even the calculated OI values are not so high. Consequently, the description of grain boundary structures by OI is more suitable for the membranes with higher Co% (>10%). Although it is not clear why the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane encounters the maximum value of OI, the experiment results can still provide further understanding.
elements.clean_text: The bimetallic membranes were then characterized by XRD and Attenuated Total Reflection Infrared Spectroscopy (ATR-IR), and all the XRD and ATR-IR patterns of the membranes match well with those of simulated ZIF-67 (i-j, Figure S5). Especially from XRD results, we find the relative intensity of the (002) reflection of the bimetallic membranes significantly changes with Co%. It means the bimetallic membranes show different degrees of orientation (Figure S6, Table S3), which can be expressed by the Orientation Index (OI). Since a large OI value (>1) indicates an increasing orientation and the oriented MOF layer is beneficial to obtain a better grain boundary structure, here we use OI values to define the quality of the membrane grain boundary structures. It is reported that ZIF-8 membranes often have good grain boundary structures, so a small substitution percentage of Zn for Co (such as 10%) will not cause significant damage to the frameworks; even the calculated OI values are not so high. Consequently, the description of grain boundary structures by OI is more suitable for the membranes with higher Co% (>10%). Although it is not clear why the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane encounters the maximum value of OI, the experiment results can still provide further understanding.

elements.content: We measured the C3H6/C3H8 separation performance of the bimetallic membranes by the Wicke–Kallenbach technique (Figure S7) and obtained two independent “volcano” type diagrams (a, Figure S8). The separation factor and gas permeance both change with Co%, but not with the same trend. The C3H6/C3H8 separation factor first climbs with the increasing Co%, peaks at Co% of 18%, and then ramps down. In contrast, the C3H6 permeance exhibits an opposite trend. It is obvious that the framework rigidity contributes greatly to the separation performance, but it is not the only contributor. When Co% is below 18% (yellow line), increasing the framework rigidity by increasing Co% is effective to improve the sieving selectivity. When Co% is above 18% (magenta line), the enhanced lattice rigidity fails to further improve the molecular sieving; worse yet, it decreases. This implies there must be another factor counteracting the contribution of the framework rigidity, namely the grain boundary structure.
elements.clean_text: We measured the C3H6/C3H8 separation performance of the bimetallic membranes by the Wicke-Kallenbach technique (Figure S7) and obtained two independent "volcano" type diagrams (a, Figure S8). The separation factor and gas permeance both change with Co%, but not with the same trend. The C3H6/C3H8 separation factor first climbs with the increasing Co%, peaks at Co% of 18%, and then ramps down. In contrast, the C3H6 permeance exhibits an opposite trend. It is obvious that the framework rigidity contributes greatly to the separation performance, but it is not the only contributor. When Co% is below 18% (yellow line), increasing the framework rigidity by increasing Co% is effective to improve the sieving selectivity. When Co% is above 18% (magenta line), the enhanced lattice rigidity fails to further improve the molecular sieving; worse yet, it decreases. This implies there must be another factor counteracting the contribution of the framework rigidity, namely the grain boundary structure.

elements.content: (a) Two “volcano” diagrams of the C3H6/C3H8 separation performance for bimetallic membranes. (b) Correlation between the Orientation Index (OI) and separation performance of the membranes. (c) Correlation between the separation factors and OI values as a function of Co%. (d) A map predicting the separation performance of bimetallic membranes. The red peak represents the targeted area when designing bimetallic membranes.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Two "volcano" diagrams of the C3H6/C3H8 separation performance for bimetallic membranes. (b) Correlation between the Orientation Index (OI) and separation performance of the membranes. (c) Correlation between the separation factors and OI values as a function of Co%. (d) A map predicting the separation performance of bimetallic membranes. The red peak represents the targeted area when designing bimetallic membranes.

elements.content: To understand how the grain boundary structure contributes to the membrane selectivity, the magenta data of a are plotted as a function of OI (b). The separation factor first increases drastically with OI value and then keeps rising slowly, which can be fitted as a logarithmic function. The gradient of this logarithmic function represents the first derivative of the logarithmic curve after OI and describes how fast the separation factor rises with increasing OI but approaches zero at high OI values, where the framework rigidity significantly decreases (lower Co%, b). This means improving the grain boundary structure is efficient to ameliorate the selectivity, but it is not the exclusive contributor, because the improvement would reach the ceiling due to the framework flexibility even if the grain boundary structure is good enough. A similar conclusion could be found when comparing the separation factors and OI values (c). When Co% increases from 18% to 41%, the OI value and separation factor both decrease but the OI value drops faster. This means the separation factor is not exclusively dominated by the grain boundary structure and the increased framework rigidity tends to relieve the negative impact from the poor grain boundary structure.
elements.clean_text: To understand how the grain boundary structure contributes to the membrane selectivity, the magenta data of a are plotted as a function of OI (b). The separation factor first increases drastically with OI value and then keeps rising slowly, which can be fitted as a logarithmic function. The gradient of this logarithmic function represents the first derivative of the logarithmic curve after OI and describes how fast the separation factor rises with increasing OI but approaches zero at high OI values, where the framework rigidity significantly decreases (lower Co%, b). This means improving the grain boundary structure is efficient to ameliorate the selectivity, but it is not the exclusive contributor, because the improvement would reach the ceiling due to the framework flexibility even if the grain boundary structure is good enough. A similar conclusion could be found when comparing the separation factors and OI values (c). When Co% increases from 18% to 41%, the OI value and separation factor both decrease but the OI value drops faster. This means the separation factor is not exclusively dominated by the grain boundary structure and the increased framework rigidity tends to relieve the negative impact from the poor grain boundary structure.

elements.content: It is obvious there is a “seesaw” behavior between the framework rigidity and the grain boundary structure. The Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane represents a “sweet spot” offering the best C3H6/C3H8 separation factor up to 200 (Table S4). To predict the membrane quality, a separation factor contour map as the function of grain boundary structure and framework rigidity has been developed (d). Route I describes the case that too much emphasis is put on the framework rigidity and too little on the grain boundary structure which results in low separation factors. In contrast, Route II represents the case of too much emphasis on the grain boundary structure while ignoring the framework rigidity. Route III represents a good balance between the grain boundary structure and the framework flexibility, enabling identification of membranes with the optimal separation performance, such as the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane.
elements.clean_text: It is obvious there is a "seesaw" behavior between the framework rigidity and the grain boundary structure. The Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane represents a "sweet spot" offering the best C3H6/C3H8 separation factor up to 200 (Table S4). To predict the membrane quality, a separation factor contour map as the function of grain boundary structure and framework rigidity has been developed (d). Route I describes the case that too much emphasis is put on the framework rigidity and too little on the grain boundary structure which results in low separation factors. In contrast, Route II represents the case of too much emphasis on the grain boundary structure while ignoring the framework rigidity. Route III represents a good balance between the grain boundary structure and the framework flexibility, enabling identification of membranes with the optimal separation performance, such as the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane.

elements.content: Moreover, the single-gas permeation through the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane has been studied (Figure S9). It shows a clear cutoff between C3H6 and C3H8, with an ideal selectivity of 200. Indeed, the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane exhibits one of the best C3H6/C3H8 separation performances among all the reported polymer and MOF membranes (a). Our bimetallic membranes exhibit great advantages, beyond the upper bounds of the polymer and pristine ZIF-8 membrane. It is shown in b that the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane shows excellent long-term stability and can maintain its C3H6/C3H8 separation performance over 200 h. Additionally, our Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane exhibits excellent thermal stability and it can fully recover to its original value after cooling from 125 °C to room temperature (c). Furthermore, the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane can be operated under elevated feed pressure (up to 2.5 bar, d). The separation factor decreases with increasing temperature and pressure, but the C3H6/C3H8 separation performance returns to the initial value completely after reducing the pressure and cooling to room temperature. This indicates that under the elevated pressure most probably only gate-opening phenomena happen that allow larger molecules to pass through but no cracks appear.
elements.clean_text: Moreover, the single-gas permeation through the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane has been studied (Figure S9). It shows a clear cutoff between C3H6 and C3H8, with an ideal selectivity of 200. Indeed, the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane exhibits one of the best C3H6/C3H8 separation performances among all the reported polymer and MOF membranes (a). Our bimetallic membranes exhibit great advantages, beyond the upper bounds of the polymer and pristine ZIF-8 membrane. It is shown in b that the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane shows excellent long-term stability and can maintain its C3H6/C3H8 separation performance over 200 h. Additionally, our Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane exhibits excellent thermal stability and it can fully recover to its original value after cooling from 125 °C to room temperature (c). Furthermore, the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane can be operated under elevated feed pressure (up to 2.5 bar, d). The separation factor decreases with increasing temperature and pressure, but the C3H6/C3H8 separation performance returns to the initial value completely after reducing the pressure and cooling to room temperature. This indicates that under the elevated pressure most probably only gate-opening phenomena happen that allow larger molecules to pass through but no cracks appear.

elements.content: (a) Comparison of C3H6/C3H8 separation performance of our bimetallic membranes with polymer, ZIF-8, and ZIF-67 membranes. (b) Long-term stability of the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane for C3H6/C3H8 separation. (c) Temperature-swing operation for the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane. (d) Gas permeance and C3H6/C3H8 separation factor of the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane as a function of the feed pressure from 1 to 2.5 bar at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Comparison of C3H6/C3H8 separation performance of our bimetallic membranes with polymer, ZIF-8, and ZIF-67 membranes. (b) Long-term stability of the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane for C3H6/C3H8 separation. (c) Temperature-swing operation for the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane. (d) Gas permeance and C3H6/C3H8 separation factor of the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane as a function of the feed pressure from 1 to 2.5 bar at room temperature.

elements.content: In summary, we prepared a series of bimetallic Zn(100–x)Co x -ZIF membranes by a facile one-step fast current driven synthesis method within 20 min. Two “volcano” diagrams were obtained for the C3H6/C3H8 separation performance of Co/Zn bimetallic membranes, which reveals the “seesaw” behavior between the grain boundary structure and framework flexibility. Furthermore, the orientation index (OI) and the Co% have been identified as the two key parameters for the understanding of the separation factor. The best balance between the two factors (the framework flexibility and the grain boundary structure) was found for the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane, which showed a C3H6/C3H8 separation factor of 200 with excellent stability. Such study highlights the delicate balance between the grain boundary structure and the framework flexibility when designing high-quality molecular sieving MOF membranes.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we prepared a series of bimetallic Zn(100-x)Co x -ZIF membranes by a facile one-step fast current driven synthesis method within 20 min. Two "volcano" diagrams were obtained for the C3H6/C3H8 separation performance of Co/Zn bimetallic membranes, which reveals the "seesaw" behavior between the grain boundary structure and framework flexibility. Furthermore, the orientation index (OI) and the Co% have been identified as the two key parameters for the understanding of the separation factor. The best balance between the two factors (the framework flexibility and the grain boundary structure) was found for the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane, which showed a C3H6/C3H8 separation factor of 200 with excellent stability. Such study highlights the delicate balance between the grain boundary structure and the framework flexibility when designing high-quality molecular sieving MOF membranes.

cln_elements.content:
Separation is one of the most energy-intensive processes in the chemical industry, and membrane-based separation technology helps to reduce the energy consumption dramatically. Supported metal–organic framework (MOF) layers hold great promise as a molecular sieve membrane, yet only a few MOF membranes showed the expected separation performance. The main reasons include e.g. nonselective grain boundary transport or the flexible MOF framework, especially the inevitable linker rotation. Here, we propose a crystal engineering strategy that balances the grain boundary structure and framework flexibility in Co–Zn bimetallic zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) membranes and exploit their contributions to the improvement of membrane quality and separation performance. It reveals that a good balance between the two trade-off factors enabled a “sweet spot” that offers the best C3H6/C3H8 separation factor up to 200.

Moreover, the single-gas permeation through the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane has been studied (Figure S9). It shows a clear cutoff between C3H6 and C3H8, with an ideal selectivity of 200. Indeed, the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane exhibits one of the best C3H6/C3H8 separation performances among all the reported polymer and MOF membranes (a). Our bimetallic membranes exhibit great advantages, beyond the upper bounds of the polymer and pristine ZIF-8 membrane. It is shown in b that the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane shows excellent long-term stability and can maintain its C3H6/C3H8 separation performance over 200 h. Additionally, our Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane exhibits excellent thermal stability and it can fully recover to its original value after cooling from 125 °C to room temperature (c). Furthermore, the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane can be operated under elevated feed pressure (up to 2.5 bar, d). The separation factor decreases with increasing temperature and pressure, but the C3H6/C3H8 separation performance returns to the initial value completely after reducing the pressure and cooling to room temperature. This indicates that under the elevated pressure most probably only gate-opening phenomena happen that allow larger molecules to pass through but no cracks appear.

Separation is one of the most energy-intensive processes in the chemical industry, and membrane-based separation technology helps to reduce the energy consumption dramatically. Supported metal-organic framework (MOF) layers hold great promise as a molecular sieve membrane, yet only a few MOF membranes showed the expected separation performance. The main reasons include e.g. nonselective grain boundary transport or the flexible MOF framework, especially the inevitable linker rotation. Here, we propose a crystal engineering strategy that balances the grain boundary structure and framework flexibility in Co-Zn bimetallic zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) membranes and exploit their contributions to the improvement of membrane quality and separation performance. It reveals that a good balance between the two trade-off factors enabled a "sweet spot" that offers the best C3H6/C3H8 separation factor up to 200.

Moreover, the single-gas permeation through the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane has been studied (Figure S9). It shows a clear cutoff between C3H6 and C3H8, with an ideal selectivity of 200. Indeed, the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane exhibits one of the best C3H6/C3H8 separation performances among all the reported polymer and MOF membranes (a). Our bimetallic membranes exhibit great advantages, beyond the upper bounds of the polymer and pristine ZIF-8 membrane. It is shown in b that the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane shows excellent long-term stability and can maintain its C3H6/C3H8 separation performance over 200 h. Additionally, our Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane exhibits excellent thermal stability and it can fully recover to its original value after cooling from 125 °C to room temperature (c). Furthermore, the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane can be operated under elevated feed pressure (up to 2.5 bar, d). The separation factor decreases with increasing temperature and pressure, but the C3H6/C3H8 separation performance returns to the initial value completely after reducing the pressure and cooling to room temperature. This indicates that under the elevated pressure most probably only gate-opening phenomena happen that allow larger molecules to pass through but no cracks appear.

A balance between the lattice rigidity and grain boundary structure is beneficial to obtain the optimal separation selectivity. However, considering one factor too much (framework rigidity or grain boundary) while ignoring the other is unfavorable for high sieving ability.

The intensity of the (002) reflection of the bimetallic membranes varied a lot, indicating the bimetallic membranes show different degrees of orientation.

(i-j) XRD patterns of the bimetallic membranes compared with the pure ZIF-67 (100% Co). The intensity of the (002) reflection of the bimetallic membranes varied a lot, indicating the bimetallic membranes show different degrees of orientation.

cln_elements.content: (a) Two “volcano” diagrams of the C3H6/C3H8 separation performance for bimetallic membranes. (b) Correlation between the Orientation Index (OI) and separation performance of the membranes. (c) Correlation between the separation factors and OI values as a function of Co%. (d) A map predicting the separation performance of bimetallic membranes. The red peak represents the targeted area when designing bimetallic membranes.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Two "volcano" diagrams of the C3H6/C3H8 separation performance for bimetallic membranes. (b) Correlation between the Orientation Index (OI) and separation performance of the membranes. (c) Correlation between the separation factors and OI values as a function of Co%. (d) A map predicting the separation performance of bimetallic membranes. The red peak represents the targeted area when designing bimetallic membranes.

cln_elements.content: (a) Comparison of C3H6/C3H8 separation performance of our bimetallic membranes with polymer, ZIF-8, and ZIF-67 membranes. (b) Long-term stability of the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane for C3H6/C3H8 separation. (c) Temperature-swing operation for the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane. (d) Gas permeance and C3H6/C3H8 separation factor of the Zn82Co18-ZIF membrane as a function of the feed pressure from 1 to 2.5 bar at room temperature.
